ygData.subject: Adaptive Representations for NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: So a few days back I mentioned some adaptive representations work I ve been doing using NEAT to study the effects of development on evolvability. This

Subject: Adaptive Representations for NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=151231063; y=0Z-3ebYdbYUZqv5zu57RxVol-MtyDVd0_Xekhgy65F9RNA
X-Yahoo-Profile: joeraii

So a few days back I mentioned some adaptive representations work  
I've been doing using NEAT to study the effects of "development" on  
evolvability. This research has some of the same goals as Ken's CPPN  
work, but the approach is quite different. Using a very simple  
"indirect" encoding of neural network weights that has some of the  
features found in GRNs in biology, we show (empirically) that both  
the final performance and sample complexity of NeuroEvolution can be  
improved in a coevolutionary setting.

But the story gets even better: Making random mutations to the  
champions that result from the GRN-like encoding, we find that  
performance degrades much more slowly than when the same number of  
mutations are made to NEAT-encoded networks. Furthermore, if we plot  
this fitness degradation against network distance instead of mutation  
distance, we find that each mutation is having a vastly larger  
phenotypic effect on the GRN-encoded neural nets. In other words  
performance is decreasing /less/ even when we make /larger/ changes  
to the network topology and weights. This kind of artifact is exactly  
what we'd like to see in so-called "evolvable" encodings: The  
representation has learned to bias the effects of mutation towards  
better networks

Anyway, this work is definitely still only a first step, but I find  
it very exciting. My paper is even going up against Ken's CPPN paper  
for the best paper award in the GDS track at GECCO. Wish me luck :)

If you are at all interested, you should definitely take a look:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?reisinger:gecco07

-- Joe
